reasoning: The critique targets Section 2.4’s multiplicative “product of factors” model, which is an important (but not indispensable) support for the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion; the essay also leans heavily on the broader catalogue of moral-catastrophe possibilities (2.1–2.3) and the more formal ‘fussy views’ analysis (Section 3). So centrality is moderate. Against 2.4 specifically, the critique substantially weakens the inference from ‘many dimensions matter’ to ‘mostly-great futures are extremely rare’ by highlighting that independence, near-zero floors, and strict complementarity are doing the work, and that plausible alternative structures (correlation, substitutability, thresholds, additive/lexical aggregation) would blunt the needle-threading result. Most claims are correct: the toy model is illustrative and not well-empirically grounded, and many moral theories won’t be naturally multiplicative or smoothly cardinal across heterogeneous goods. A minor overstatement is that the essay provides no theoretical connection at all (it gestures at analogous multiplicative/fat-tailed patterns), but it still doesn’t establish the specific independence/uniform assumptions. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight. Overall it poses a real but limited threat to the position because it undercuts one argumentative pillar rather than the full case.
title: The multiplicative model's independence assumption lacks empirical and theoretical justification
